newsitem.title: MAURITIUS: Cassam Uteem re-elected Mauritian president.
newsitem.headline: Cassam Uteem re-elected Mauritian president.

text.p: Cassam Uteem was re-elected on Saturday as president of the Indian Ocean island of Mauritius.
In a unanimous vote by parliament, Angidi Chettiar was elected vice-president. Both jobs are largely ceremonial because the head of government on the island is the prime minister.
The two motions for the elections were proposed by the Prime Minister Navin Ramgoolam and seconded by former deputy prime minister and now leader of the opposition Paul Berenger.
Uteem was first elected president in 1992. Ramgoolam and Berenger had already agreed on renewing Uteem's term before their coalition goverment collapsed last week.

"I can say to this house without any fear of contradiction and without any hesitation that he (Uteem) has always shown fairness, sincerity of purpose, a sharp logical mind and decency," Ramgoolam told parliament.
Chettiar replaces Rabindranath Ghurburrun. Since 1952, Chettiar has been a member of the Labour Party that is led by Ramgoolam.
